title: Compile error using re-exported empty generic struct from another crate

labels.name: I-compiletime
labels.description: Problems and improvements with respect to compile times.

body:
I've defined a unit-like struct that is generic over one type (`Phantom<T>`) in an inner module of a library. It is then re-exported from the root module. Instantiating it within the library works fine, but trying to use it from a program that links to the library results in a compile error.

library `foo.rs`:

```
pub use inner::Phantom;

pub mod inner {
    pub struct Phantom<T>;
}
```

binary `main.rs`:

```
extern crate foo;

use foo::Phantom;

struct A;

fn main() {
    Phantom::<A>;
}
```

compile error:

```
$ rustc --crate-type lib foo.rs && rustc main.rs -L .
main.rs:8:15: 8:16 error: too many type parameters provided: expected at most 0 parameter(s), found 1 parameter(s) [E0087]
main.rs:8     Phantom::<A>;
                        ^
error: aborting due to previous error
```

For this to trigger, `foo` has to be a separate crate -- if I recreate the same module hierarchy within `main.rs`, it compiles.

If `main.rs` doesn't use the re-export, but accesses the struct directly (`use foo::inner::Phantom`) it also compiles fine.

If I add any fields to the struct, it compiles without any issues as well.

Triggered on:

```
$ rustc --version verbose
rustc 0.12.0-nightly (d64b4103d 2014-09-26 21:47:47 +0000)
binary: rustc
commit-hash: d64b4103d688f38c2e9e2daf966d50beeb383f1e
commit-date: 2014-09-26 21:47:47 +0000
host: x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu
release: 0.12.0-nightly
```
